Expectation1: Ensure client satisfaction and address any concerns or complaints professionally
Situation1: A first-time visitor looks disappointed with the colour tone in the mirror.
Situation2: An invited guest speaker has prepared a sermon and can take the pulpit if needed.
Story: I glanced at the clock above my station, my hands still trembling from the last brushstroke of dye. The first-time client in my chair stared at her reflection, lips pressed tight, eyes flickering with disappointment. I could feel her expectation—she wanted me to fix it, to listen, to make it right. My phone buzzed in my pocket, a reminder of the time. Friday prayers were less than an hour away. As the imam, I was expected to deliver the Khutbah, to guide the congregation, to be present in both body and spirit. But today, the guest speaker was ready, his notes in hand, prepared to step in if I couldn’t make it. My heart pounded as I weighed the client’s growing frustration against the sacred duty awaiting me at the mosque. I could see both worlds pulling at me—one demanding my professional care and attention, the other my spiritual leadership. I stood there, scissors in hand, caught between the mirror and the minbar, unsure which expectation I would have to let down.
